title-group.article-title: Practical Guide to Understanding Multivariable Analyses, Part B
title-group.subtitle: Conjunctive Consolidation

article-meta.aff: 1Practical Guides Writing Group, Department of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, Missouri, USA

author-notes.corresp: J. (John) Gail Neely, MD, Professor and Director, Otology/Neurotology/Base of Skull Surgery, Department of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery, Washington University School of Medicine, 660 S. Euclid Ave, Box 8115, St Louis, MO 63110, USA Email: jgneely@aol.com; neelyg@ent.wustl.edu

abstract.p: Conjunctive consolidation, one method of multivariable analysis by arranging data into clusters, is intuitive and transparent. An unexpected consequence in writing this article was the discovery of just how useful it is in critically analyzing articles and in designing new projects. It has stimulated a fresh understanding as to the value of multivariable thinking in all clinical research. This article is organized into the sequential steps for performing conjunctive consolidation for critically analyzing an article of interest and for completing the process, pending all required data are available. Investigators, particularly those who perform clinical research, should consider conjunctive consolidation as a valuable method of multivariable analysis with which to report data.

body.p: Writing about multivariable analysis has had some unexpected and amazing consequences. One needs only to share with a colleague something about multivariable analysis to see his or her eyes glaze over. The thought of multivariable analysis often elicits a negative visceral response, and one can become overwhelmed and disconnected from the very beginning.

Conversely, arranging data into clusters is transparent; one can see exactly what is happening. Conjunctive consolidation is a multivariable method that arranges data into clusters and allows an investigator to think about the relevance of all the variables. Amazingly, it stimulates the tendency to think in multivariable terms when critically reviewing articles and designing new projects. Clinical research is complex, with a myriad of variables that may influence a target outcome. It is prudent, therefore, that projects be designed and reported with multivariable effects in mind.

This article is organized into the sequential steps for performing conjunctive consolidation for critically analyzing an article of interest and for completing the process, pending all required data are available (Table 1).

tr.th: (A) Basic Organization of Designing Data Collection
Variable A: Category a1 or Category a2 or Category a3
Variable B: Category b1 or Category b2
Variable D: Category d1 or Category d2 or Category d3 or Category d4

tr.td:
Assessment for data adequacy
Are all of the important variables of interest considered?
Are there enough data available for these variables that the target outcomes associated with each category can be determined? In addition, are there enough data to support internal cells for conjoining variables?
Is the number of subjects in each variable category at or above the modicum of 20 subjects/subgroup?

Assessment of intercategorical gradients and bivariate analysis
Are the intercategorical gradients greater than 10%?
b. Are the category outcomes statistically significant?

Examining candidate conjunctions and conjoining variables
If the number of variables is k, then k(k − 1)/2 tables can be created.
Select the initial pairing for consolidation:
Is the pairing of variables biologically or clinically sensible?
Is there a double gradient?

Consolidation
Cluster cells that have similar target outcomes and pathobiology or other scientific medical attributes.
New composite stages typically expand the gradients of the variables.

sec.title: Overview, Rationale, and Utility
sec.p: As described in Part A, multivariable analyses are used to determine the degree and direction of effects that independent (predictor) variables have on the dependent (outcome) variable, in addition to the main independent variable under study (such as treatment).1 These techniques may be categorized as (1) mathematical models, as discussed in Part A, or (2) cluster arrangements.2 One commonly used technique of arranging data into clusters is conjunctive consolidation. Part A was designed to give the reader a general understanding of the complex mathematical models. Conversely, Part B will provide the reader with a basic understanding of conjunctive consolidation and demonstrate how to perform this task, via examples that illustrate the principles of this technique.

Conjunctive consolidation aims to combine variables that independently influence the outcome, stratifying the data within the combined variables to show the composite effect on the outcome. Conjunctive consolidation examines the effects of sequential pairs of variables, first by assessing the outcome gradients of potentially important variables, then conjoining these variables into compound clusters, and ultimately consolidating the results to form a new combined variable staging system.2-8

The rationale and utility of grouping data into clusters and joining pairs of variables is the relative ease and transparency of the data review and analysis of the multivariable effects. Grouping data does not negate further algebraic analyses but does clarify what the data contain. Thus, conjunctive consolidation is an effective method to analyze one’s own research data. In addition, it is useful in studying published reports and pilot data, to understand available evidence and to focus quantitative questions for further research. It also immediately draws attention to the necessity to identify covariates that may modulate the effect of an intervention to properly design and/or critically analyze a trial. Because conjunctive consolidation intrinsically stratifies data, it is tremendously useful in the development of prognostic staging systems, such as for cancer survival. It allows many clinical factors to be incorporated into a staging system in a manner that makes clinical sense and adds complexity without increasing the number of groups or categories involved.

Table 2 and Table 3 are a glossary of terms and an illustration of the position of those terms, respectively, which can help in understanding conjunctive consolidation and provide a quick review of a published article.

tr.td: A characteristic or attribute of a person, thing, or event that varies within a defined range or domain. Examples: age, height, disease, test results

The subunit of a variable within the defined range or domain in which characteristic may vary. Examples: age categories: minor, young adult, middle-aged adult, old adult; height categories: tall, medium, short; disease categories: diabetes mellitus (DM), no DM; test results categories: positive, negative

A group of subjects within 1 category from 1 variable or a group of subjects within a category formed by consolidating several categories from several variables. Examples: simple (single) category cluster: young adults; compound (composite) category cluster: young adult, short, diabetic, test-positive subjects
m = number of ranked categories of a variable
Examples from “categories” above: age: m = 4; height: m = 3; disease: m = 2; test: m = 2
Examples: age: m − 1 = 3; height: m − 1 = 2; disease: m − 1 = 1; test: m − 1 = 1
Each variable being conjoined has a significant target gradient, suggesting an important independent effect on outcome

Minimal acceptable percentage difference (gradient) between clusters achieving the target (outcome) variable of interest of 10% or greater. Examples of age-variable clusters having the target variable “healthy”: minors 100%, young adults 90%, middle aged 70%, old 30%Intercategory gradients: 10%, 20%, 40%

Minimal total percentage gradient for the whole variable system is number of intercategorical gradients available times the minimum intercategory gradient. This is (m − 1) * 10%.Example: age intercategorical gradients available = 3 times 10% = 30% = minimal intrasystem gradient. Examples of age-variable clusters having the target variable “healthy”: minors 100%, young 90%, middle aged 70%, old 30%; total intrasystem gradient 100 − 30 = 70% (passes the minimum)

Single or composite categories relating to the target variable. Examples: single-variable categories for age forming 4 strata: minor, young adult, middle aged, old; composite variable categories for specific height and age forming 2 strata: short, middle aged
Modicum = minimum size of subgroup (stratum or cell)
Twenty subjects/stratum or cell are required for statistical stability. Examples: age having 4 strata: 20 * 4 = 80; composite variable age and height forming 2 strata: 20 * 2 = 40.

Similar to modicum in conjunctive consolidation, target events per each independent variable in algebraic multivariable analysis models require 20 events/variable for statistical stability; less than 10 events/variable is very unstable. Example: 4 variables require 80 events or at least 40 events.
Optimum number of strata in a staging system

Tables formed by conjoining pairs of variables. Total available tables that can be formed from k variables. For k variables, number of tables = k(k − 1)/2; thus, for 4 variables, 4 * 3/2 = 12/2 = 6 tables
Pairwise conjunction of variables (tables) to form a new composite variable
Process of consolidating 2 or more categories of the new composite variable into a staging system
Find and combine the most important variables that influence the target variable of interest (usually outcome)

Adjacent cells (same row, or same column, or touching diagonally) in a cross-tabulation of 2 variables having similar biological characteristics (biological similarity) and similar target outcome rates (statistical isometry)
Neighboring cells having similar target (outcome) rates
Subjects in a stratum, or a composite category, having similar (concordant) pathobiology or other scientific medical attributes that justify conjunction

fn.p: t = number of subjects achieving target outcome; n = total number in cluster; t/n = proportion of subjects achieving target outcome; (%) = t/n as a percentage for determining gradients (% difference between clusters).

sec.title: Performing Conjunctive Consolidation
sec.p: Conjunctive consolidation analyzes categorical variables (nominal, dichotomous, ordinal scales). Dimensional (continuous) variables must be segmented into a dichotomous or ordinal scale for analysis (eg, dividing age into young, middle, old). The target outcome (dependent) variable must be binary (eg, incomplete or complete recovery of facial function). The levels into which categorical variables may vary are known as categories.

The transparency of conjunctive consolidation compels multivariable thinking. This can be seen even when a full conjunctive consolidation cannot be done because of lack of enough data. To illustrate this, we looked at Peitersen’s beautiful supplement on 1701 untreated Bell’s palsy patients, often quoted as a “gold standard” of the natural history of Bell’s palsy.9 Peitersen analyzed many variables for their association with recovery of facial function; this setting is optimal for the use of conjunctive consolidation to develop a prognostic staging system for facial function recovery.

sec.title: Step 1: Assessment of Data Adequacy
sec.p: Three quick things to look at to determine the adequacy of the data are the following:

list-item.p: Are most or all of the independent predictor variables of interest considered in the study? For example, Peitersen9 studied the variables of sex, age, taste dysfunction, Schirmer tear test results, degree of onset paralysis, postauricular pain, stapedial reflexes, and pregnancy, which are all variables of interest in studying recovery of facial function.

Are there enough data available for these variables that the outcomes associated with each category can be determined? In addition, are there enough data to support the internal cells for conjoining variables? In other words, all the individual patient data must be accessible, rather than just group summaries.

sec.p: The application of conjunctive consolidation to analysis of the literature is often limited by the absence of raw data. This is illustrated with the data presented in Peitersen’s article.9 Embarking on this journey into understanding conjunctive consolidation, we were initially excited by the possibility of applying conjunctive consolidation to these data to construct a prognostic system for Bell’s palsy. There were abundant data for each variable category associated with outcomes. However, there was not sufficient transparency of the data to support internal cells for conjoining variables. Most instructive was realizing that one cannot perform conjunctive consolidation without actual raw data. Despite the impossibility of completing a full conjunction because of missing data, the utility of the transparency of this multivariable look unexpectedly revealed a potential completely new understanding of Bell’s palsy. Even though conjunctive consolidation could not be completed, attempting to configure the available data into that format resulted in a new discovery of just how important age may be on full recovery from Bell’s palsy. This exemplified another principle of discovery: failure to achieve a goal can sometimes be more instructive than when all goes as planned.

In addition, it should be remembered that the usual “Table 1” in most clinical research, which compares the baseline variables in the groups, is designed to determine whether the groups are comparable. That table does not substitute for determining the effect of those variables on the outcome.

list-item.p: 3. Are the number of subjects in each variable category at or above the modicum of 20 subjects/category, or does the total number of subjects suggest that there may be 20 or more subjects in each category? Looking at the variable with the most categories helps determine the general adequacy of numbers. For example, if there are 10 variables and 5 seem biologically sensible, and 1 variable has 4 categories and the others have 3 or 2 categories, the 4-category variable should have 4 × 20 or 80 subjects or more. Peitersen’s work9 had enough subjects, just not enough detailed information allowing conjunction.

sec.title: Step 2: Assessment of Intercategorical Gradients and Bivariate Analysis
sec.p: Realizing it was not possible to continue conjunctive consolidation using Peitersen’s work,9 a hypothetical data set was constructed using “poor recovery of facial function in facial paralysis” as the target outcome (Table 4). Two variables were formulated, 1 with 3 categories (eg, “age”) and the other with 2 categories (eg, “severity of paralysis at onset”). The proportion of subjects in each stratum within a single categorical variable having the target outcome (Y) of “incomplete recovery” is listed in the middle column. The intercategorical gradient of each stratum exceeded the 10% minimum intercategorical gradient and the minimum intrasystem gradient (m − 1 * 10%), as well as the 20% required minimum for variable A and 10% for variable B.

caption.p: Hypothetical Data Set for Conjunctive Consolidation

tr.td: Two predictor variables passing bivariate analysis:
Variable A, age: 3 categories, with 16%, 29%, and 51% having outcome Y
Variable B, onset paralysis: 2 categories, with 21% and 43% having outcome Y

tr.th: Target Outcomes of Poor Recovery (Y) in Facial Paralysis

sec.p: Bivariate analysis was performed to see if the outcome rates between categories within each variable were statistically different. To do this, a contingency table was constructed with 2 columns and enough rows for each variable, with the number of subjects with outcome Y in one column and the number without the outcome Y in the other. The rows were the categories in each variable. Bivariate analysis for proportions using χ2 was calculated; the P value is shown for each variable.

Importantly, when these data were constructed, each variable was hypothetically deemed to have scientific medical attributes that were sensibly related to the target outcome and would justify conjunctive consolidation.

sec.title: Step 3: Examining Candidate Conjunctions and Conjoining Variables
sec.p: In this step, each independent variable is paired with another, and combined outcomes are calculated in a table format. For the number k variables, k(k − 1)/2 tables are generated. The choice of the first table to analyze can be complex and relies on the pair of variables that makes the most biologic sense and the table with the largest double gradient. To highlight biologic sensibility, let’s return to our example of Bell’s palsy. A table conjoining degree of paralysis at onset and age may have more clinical applicability than a table conjoining degree of paralysis at onset and Schirmer test results, if one recognizes that an emergency department or primary care physician initially evaluates most facial paralyses and may have limited accessibility to Schirmer testing.

In the hypothetical data set, we chose to begin consolidation with conjoining variables A (age) and B (severity of paralysis at onset) due to their biologic sensibility (Table 5A). When configuring the combination of variables, gradients must go from best on the left to worst on the right and from best on the top to worst on the bottom. Best is relative to the target outcome. For example, if poor recovery is the target being analyzed, then the lowest rate is best; conversely, if good recovery is the target, the highest survival rate is the best. This configuration allows the subsequent consolidation of categories into new stages to be like “peeling the onion”—in other words, joining groups of categories from best to worst in aggregates while peeling away separate cells (J. F. Piccirillo, personal communication, 2012).

caption.p: Hypothetical Data Set for Conjunctive Consolidation

tr.th: (A) Conjunction (Outcome Target Poor Recovery of Facial Function)
(B) Consolidation (Outcome Target Poor Recovery of Facial Function)

fn.p: Result: New predictor variable, age-onset, with 4 levels: 5% 23%, 38%, and 60%. Consolidated internal cells are compound (composite) category clusters.

sec.p: Importantly, the table shows a crucial double gradient. Double gradient refers to the fact that each variable has a significant target gradient (equal to or greater than the minimal intercategorical gradient of 10%), suggesting an important independent effect on outcome. Also note that the sum of the numbers achieving the target outcome variable divided by the total numbers of the conjoining variables are the same; this is seen in the far bottom right marginal cell. This confirms that all the subjects are included in both variables.

sec.title: Step 4: Consolidating Variables
sec.p: Table 5B demonstrates the consolidation of the conjoined variables. Neighboring cells can be clustered according to categories with similar biologic characteristics and similar target outcomes. Consolidation of cells is performed using the concept of ordered neighbors in which adjacent 2 or more cells in the same row or columns or touching diagonally are joined into the same stage.

The purpose of conjunctive consolidation is to devise a clinically meaningful staging system when there is more than 1 variable that is important in predicting the outcome. This process generates a staging system gradient greater than either variable alone. In this example, the variable A “age” gradient ranged from 16% to 51% (difference 35%), and the variable B “severity of paralysis at onset” gradient ranged from 21% to 43% (difference 22%); the new age-onset variable staging system ranged from 5% to 60% (difference 55%).

It is possible to conjoin and consolidate other variables with the initial staging system. However, consolidating more than 3 variables is rarely fruitful and can be confusing. Table 6 illustrates the addition of a third hypothetical variable, “comorbidities.” This variable was considered clinically important, had appropriate gradients, and showed a statistically significant difference between categories. This new staging system (age-onset-comorbidity) generated a gradient from 8% to 75% (difference 67%).

caption.p: Conjunctive Consolidation: Addition of a Third Hypothetical Variable: Comorbidities

sec.p: Initially, we debated using only generic terms, such as variables A, B, and C, but instead chose to use potentially clinically meaningful terms for the hypothetically constructed data. This seemed to enhance and simplify further thought on the value of conjunctive consolidation. Table 7 demonstrates how an evidence-based, data-driven (albeit hypothetical data) process such as conjunctive consolidation can lead to a prognostic stratification relative to an outcome. Once a substantive staging system has been developed using multivariable techniques to account for the conjoined effects of predictor variables, further refinements can be made to the system by validating against new data and determining treatment effects within the multivariable environment.

caption.p: Hypothetical New Prognostic Stratification Organized Like TMN Staging

tr.td: Alpha: age 0-30, incomplete @ onset, few or many comorbidities 8%
Or age 0-30, complete @ onset, few comorbidities
Or age 31-60, incomplete @ onset, few comorbidities
Beta: age >60, incomplete @ onset, few comorbidities 30%
Or age 31-60, complete @ onset, few comorbidities
Or age 0-30, complete @ onset, many comorbidities
Or age 31-60, incomplete @ onset, many comorbidities
Gamma: age >60, complete @ onset, few comorbidities 51%
Or age >60, incomplete @ onset, many comorbidities
Or age 31-60, complete @ onset, many comorbidities
Delta: age >60, complete @ onset, many comorbidities 75%

fn.p: Age: A1 = 0-30; A2 = 31-60; A3 = >60. Paralysis at onset: P0 = incomplete; P1 = complete. Comorbidities: C0 = few; C1 = many.

sec.p: It should be noted that conjunctive consolidation need not work in every case. If the data do not adhere to the rules or if sufficient data are unavailable, the technique cannot be used. However, looking at data from a multivariable perspective can lead to new insights.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Conjunctive consolidation, one method of multivariable analysis by arranging data into clusters, is intuitive and transparent. An unexpected consequence in writing this article was the discovery of just how useful it is in critically analyzing articles and in designing new projects. It has stimulated a fresh understanding as to the value of multivariable thinking in all clinical research. Investigators, particularly those who perform clinical research, should consider conjunctive consolidation as a valuable method of multivariable analysis with which to report data.
